headline.main: A Successful Journey From Delusion to Reality

docs.abstract: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; Ramon Lebron discusses how he received help overcoming schizophrenia at Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service; photo (M)

keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: When Ramon Lebron saw Neil Armstrong walking on the moon in 1969, he thought he was up there with him. In actuality, Ramon was a 12-year-old boy watching television at home in the East New York section of Brooklyn. But in his mind, the distinction between reality and imagining had already begun to blur.

headline.main: Subway Killing Casts Light On Suspect's Mental Torment

docs.abstract: Many who knew 29-year-old Andrew Goldstein, who is accused of pushing Kendra Webdale to death under Manhattan subway train on January 3, portray him as was forlorn, rootless and frustrated man in grip of schizophrenia; Goldstein biographical profile; advocates for mentally ill say Goldstein is one more person neglected by system, and that tragedy reinforces notion that there is too little money and too few programs to serve needy population that is no longer kept in hospitals; photos (M)
docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

byline.original: By N. R. KLEINFIELD with KIT R. ROANE

docs.lead_paragraph: As far back as when he was 16 and first had an inkling that something was wrong with him, his life appeared to turn inward and downward. Until the police took him away, he lived in a basement shoe box of a room in Queens. He watched ''The Simpsons'' and listened to Pink Floyd and ceaselessly paced the linoleum floor. He would prattle on about becoming a business executive, though he never progressed beyond landing a job at a Dunkin' Donuts that lasted one day. He yearned to have an adoring wife and family, but he had no real friends.

docs.abstract: Article discusses impact on smokers of New Jersey's doubling of cigarette tax; photo; graph (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Smokers in New Jersey took such a shellacking at the cash register last year that they stopped buying cigarettes in numbers never seen before. How many stopped smoking is a separate question. Since the state cigarette tax doubled last Jan. 1, sales have declined about 12 percent, Treasury Department data show. While some sales have been chased across state borders, public health experts estimate that at least two-thirds of the decline reflects a decrease in smoking.
